subject: Photography
title: What Is Color Temperature?
description: A fast breakdown of What Is Color Temperature? for builders.

hook.text: A candle glows warm. A cloudy sky looks cool. Light itself has a temperature â€” measured in Kelvin.

buildup.text: Color temperature describes the warmth or coolness of a light source, from warm orange to cool blue.

discovery.text: Candlelight is about 1800K (warm). Daylight is 5500K (neutral). Shade is 7000K+ (cool and bluish).

twist.text: Higher Kelvin numbers mean cooler light. It's counterintuitive â€” higher temperature, bluer the light.

climax.text: Understanding color temperature lets you predict how light will look before you even raise your camera.

punchline.text: Every light source has a color. Kelvin tells you which.
